headline.main: Chinese Trials End; Fate of Hundreds Unclear

docs.snippet: In a wave of trials ending Tuesday, Chinese courts sentenced 18 of the nation's best-known dissidents to prison for terms ranging up to 13 years. But while those trials have ended, almost nothing is known about the hundreds of others who are in pri

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: In a wave of trials ending Tuesday, Chinese courts sentenced 18 of the nation's best-known dissidents to prison for terms ranging up to 13 years. But while those trials have ended, almost nothing is known about the hundreds of others who are in prison for taking part in the Tiananmen democracy movement. The Chinese have never given an accounting of those arrested in the crackdown beginning in June 1989, but most estimates are that more than 1,000 people are still in prison, detention centers or re-education camps for their involvement in the Tiananmen Square protests.

headline.main: Escape From Tiananmen Square: A Chinese Odyssey

docs.snippet: WERE YOU FOLLOWED?" LIU XIANG ASKED anxiously, by way of greeting. It was a bright September day last year when we met for dinner at a restaurant in the center of Beijing. He hardly touched his food, spending much of his time looking over his shoul
docs.lead_paragraph: WERE YOU FOLLOWED?" LIU XIANG ASKED anxiously, by way of greeting. It was a bright September day last year when we met for dinner at a restaurant in the center of Beijing. He hardly touched his food, spending much of his time looking over his shoulder. A fugitive from the law, Liu was very different from the easygoing physics student who, the year before, was at the center of the democracy movement at Tiananmen Square. "They're closing in," he said in a whisper. "The police have been asking around town about me, and I've got to leave very soon. But this time I've got to get to Hong Kong safely. Otherwise, it's all over."

headline.main: Rx: For Quick Relief On Sizzling Days; Beijing

docs.snippet: IN YOUR SEARCH FOR A Chinese summer breeze, the best path to choose is the one taken for centuries by China's Emperors and Empresses. When the heat of Beijing became unbearable, all the more stifling for the layers of silk royalty wore, the imperia
docs.lead_paragraph: IN YOUR SEARCH FOR A Chinese summer breeze, the best path to choose is the one taken for centuries by China's Emperors and Empresses. When the heat of Beijing became unbearable, all the more stifling for the layers of silk royalty wore, the imperial court would sometimes travel about seven miles northwest of the city to a tranquil lakeside enclave called the Garden of Peace and Harmony. Usually referred to as the Summer Palace, it is a sprawling, mazelike collection of halls and rooms with names like Chamber of Enjoying Prosperity and Abode in Clouds and Pines. When the weather heats up, the place fills with local Chinese, but if you go on a weekday, you can stroll in peace on the covered path beside the lake. Under the long walkway's slightly arched rooftop are more than 1,000 delicate paintings of other cool places in China.

headline.main: Beijing Students Issue Leaflets on Democracy

docs.snippet: In a rare political protest, students at Beijing University have distributed leaflets and hung a banner commemorating those killed in the military crackdown at Tiananmen Square two years ago.    The leaflets, which were flung out of dormitory windo
docs.lead_paragraph: In a rare political protest, students at Beijing University have distributed leaflets and hung a banner commemorating those killed in the military crackdown at Tiananmen Square two years ago. The leaflets, which were flung out of dormitory windows on Tuesday shortly before noon, called on people to mourn the students who died in the crackdown on the democracy movement.

docs.snippet: An American college football team turned Tiananmen Square into an impromptu practice field today, attracting curious Chinese who came up to touch the players' shoulder pads and take turns trying on their helmets.   "It was really amazing the way ev
docs.lead_paragraph: An American college football team turned Tiananmen Square into an impromptu practice field today, attracting curious Chinese who came up to touch the players' shoulder pads and take turns trying on their helmets. "It was really amazing the way everybody just swarmed around us," said Ben Maier, a reserve running back for Pacific Lutheran. "Everything we did just sort of fascinated them." Pacific Lutheran of Tacoma, Wash., will play Evangel College of Missouri in three games in China, the first on Friday in Beijing. The two also will play in Canton on June 5 and Shanghai on June 12. Friday night's game is believed to be the first American football game played in China.

headline.main: Beijing University Students Mark the 1989 Crackdown

docs.snippet: In a bold protest against China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, students at Beijing University early this morning smashed nearly 100 glass bottles to mark the second anniversary of the military crackdown here on the democracy movement.   Shortly af
docs.lead_paragraph: In a bold protest against China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, students at Beijing University early this morning smashed nearly 100 glass bottles to mark the second anniversary of the military crackdown here on the democracy movement. Shortly after midnight, students began clapping, cheering and throwing bottles outside three graduate dormitories where policemen were patrolling, a witness said. In Chinese, "xiao ping," meaning "little bottle," is a homonym for Mr. Deng's given name, and protesters often express their feelings about Mr. Deng by shattering bottles.

headline.main: In Beijing, an 18th-Century Novel Is Celebrated With a Feast

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: DREAM OF THE RED MANSION, THE (BOOK)

docs.snippet: IT was quite a scene. In the graceful, many-tiered pagodas set among the waterfalls and goldfish ponds of Zhongshan Park near Tiananmen Square, more than 300 diners set upon such niceties as stewed and seasoned mock-bear pads, pearl-in-the-bosom-of
docs.lead_paragraph: IT was quite a scene. In the graceful, many-tiered pagodas set among the waterfalls and goldfish ponds of Zhongshan Park near Tiananmen Square, more than 300 diners set upon such niceties as stewed and seasoned mock-bear pads, pearl-in-the-bosom-of-an-aged-clam and black-dragon sea cucumber, eating to the muted strains of traditional Chinese music. This was no ordinary banquet. On the second night of China's first international food conference, held here in July, the menu, the music, even the restaurant itself had been created as a sort of living, breathing paean to what could be China's most famous novel, "The Dream of the Red Mansion."

headline.main: CHINA MAKES A BID TO HOLD OLYMPICS

docs.snippet: China's leaders have a special dream for a patch of empty ground in northern Beijing: the hope that in September 2000, in a 100,000-seat stadium to be built on that spot, they will preside over the opening ceremonies of the Summer Olympic Games.
docs.lead_paragraph: China's leaders have a special dream for a patch of empty ground in northern Beijing: the hope that in September 2000, in a 100,000-seat stadium to be built on that spot, they will preside over the opening ceremonies of the Summer Olympic Games. After months of preparations, the Chinese leadership formally announced its bid today to become the host of the 27th Olympiad. Prime Minister Li Peng said in a letter sent today to the International Olympic Committee that China would try "to make the 2000 Olympic Games a grand celebration in sports marking the advent of a new millennium with a better prospect of peace and friendship."
